Description: Fragment of a small seal-impression made of fine brown Nile clay that was hardened after excavation. The rear shows a bent surface with textile impression, probably from a bag. In the break an impression of a turned cord with a width of 0.25 cm. The front is covered with finger impressions and a very small oval impression of a scarab-like seal of which the upper half is preserved. It shows a small sign on the left which could be a flag (nTr), right of it a seated Amun with double feather crown, facing to the left, behind another seated deity with red crown, facing to the left as well, behind that figure an upright uraeus. The second row is not preserved but the first sign starts with a loop like a H-sign (V28) or similar, which could be part of a horizontal sign following to the right of it. Rest is broken off.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amara West (Nubia), E14.7 temple magazine
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
